author: timesunion.com
title: Noteworthy
text:
Photo: Jeff Lewis Image 1 of / 2 Caption

Image 1 of 2 FILE - In this July 31, 2009, file photo, Los Angeles Lakers' Lamar Odom speaks to the media during a news conference after the Lakers signed Odom to a multi-year NBA basketball contract, in El Segundo, Calif. Odom spent most of his 14-year NBA career in Los Angeles with the Lakers and Clippers, becoming a fan favorite before he sought even more fame with the Kardashians. Odom, who was embraced by teammates and television fans alike for his Everyman approach to fame, was found face-down and alone Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, after spending four days at the Love Ranch, a legal Nevada brothel. (AP Photo/Jeff Lewis, File) ORG XMIT: NY171 FILE - In this July 31, 2009, file photo, Los Angeles Lakers' Lamar Odom speaks to the media during a news conference after the Lakers signed Odom to a multi-year NBA basketball contract, in El Segundo, ... more Photo: Jeff Lewis Image 2 of 2 HOUSTON, TX - MARCH 29: Head coach Mike Krzyzewski of the Duke Blue Devils cuts down the net after defeating the Gonzaga Bulldogs 66-52 in the South Regional Final of the 2015 NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament at NRG Stadium on March 29, 2015 in Houston, Texas. (Photo by Tom Pennington/Getty Images) ORG XMIT: 527066811 HOUSTON, TX - MARCH 29: Head coach Mike Krzyzewski of the Duke Blue Devils cuts down the net after defeating the Gonzaga Bulldogs 66-52 in the South Regional Final of the 2015 NCAA Men's Basketball ... more Photo: Tom Pennington Noteworthy 1 / 2 Back to Gallery Krzyzewski: '16 last Olympics he'll coach
Duke coach Mike Krzyzewski will step down from his position as the head coach of U.S. men's national team after the 2016 Olympics, according to an interview he gave to ESPN's Andy Katz .
It's not the first time Krzyzewski, 68, has made a pledge to step away from his head coaching position with USA Basketball. After winning gold at the 2012 Olympics in London, He returned to the Raleigh-Durham airport and said he was done, but he changed his mind in 2013. The plan is to announce his successor before the Rio de Janeiro Games next summer.
Krzyzewski said he'd like to stay involved in USA Basketball in a non-coaching capacity.
B aseball: Barry Zito , the 2002 AL Cy Young Award winner in Oakland, is retiring as he planned. The 37-year-old will turn his attention to music and time with his family. He went 165-143 with a 4.04 ERA in parts of 15 big-league seasons, including seven years with San Francisco.
Fantasy sports: DraftKings says a law firm hired to investigate claims an employee used valuable inside information to win a $350,000 second-place prize on a competing daily fantasy sports site contest confirms that didn't and couldn't have happened. The Boston-based company released a short two-page summary Monday saying it would have been impossible for the employee to use the information to win on FanDuel because he didn't receive the helpful data until 40 minutes after that site's contest closed. The companies' employees aren't allowed to bet on their own sites but until recently could play on competing sites.
NBA: LeBron James sat out Cleveland's preseason finale against Dallas on Monday night, but coach David Blatt said James will be ready for the season opener Oct. 27 at Chicago. James, who had an anti-inflammatory injection in his back last week, hasn't played since Oct. 12.
